Notes: Secondary and Universities allowed to hold in-person classes. Primary classes currently closed and expected to open sometime in February.    source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210202195446/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Primary schools have now re-opened since 10 February 2012. Universities and secondary level school were already allowed to hold in-person classes. Only missing are preschools (children age 3-6) which are scheduled to open March 3rd.    Strong restrictions are in place for in-person classes, including social distancing, hand-washing, etc...     sources: http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144244/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144845/https://jornalnorthnews.com/noticia/409/alunos-do-ensino-primario-voltam-as-aulas-na-angola  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-145224/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/medidas-a-vigorar-ate-11-de-marco/

Overall, sectors are open with limited capacity and some hourly restrictions.    This summarises the situation quite well: Health centers and hospitals are fully operational.  Restaurants are open from 6a.m. to 9p.m. for table service, and from 6a.m. to 10p.m. for takeout.? In person dining is limited to 50 percent capacity with no more than four guests per table.? Stores, including supermarkets, can remain open until 10p.m.? Museums and monuments, movie theaters, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are open but limited to 50 percent capacity.? Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.    sources: http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144244/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-145224/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/medidas-a-vigorar-ate-11-de-marco/

According to the US Embassy in Burundi, The Ministry of Health expanded prevention measures related to COVID-19 for all travelers arriving to Burundi.  Measures are regularly updated and subject to change without notice.  All passengers arriving at Bujumbura’s Melchior Ndadaye’s international airport will be transported to designated hotels approved by the Government of Burundi.  Travelers must make hotel reservations at Government of Burundi approved quarantine hotel before arriving.   Upon arrival, travelers will be tested at the airport for COVID-19.  Passengers whose initial test show a negative result will transit, in a shuttle under Burundi police-operated shuttle, to their hotel for a 7 day quarantine period, where there will be strict enforcement of quarantine rules, under supervision of the Burundi police.  These travelers will be control tested again on day 6 of their quarantine period and released the following day if the test shows a negative result.  Passengers who test positive, at any time, will be transferred to one of the Care Centers for monitoring at their own expense for a period of 14 days or more and required to have two negative control test results before being discharged.  The cost of a COVID-19 test is 100$. These measures and the timeline may vary, due to limitations of resources.  The Government of Burundi announced that quarantined individuals would also be responsible for the hotel costs of the quarantine.  It is advisable, when planning travel to Burundi, to take into account the possibility of additional expenses and lengthy delays due to quarantine procedures.   Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207205721/https://bi.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All travelers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR (nasal swab) test upon arrival in Ouagadougou.  The test result must be dated within five days of arrival and can be in English or French. "All travelers arriving in Burkina Faso must present proof of having tested negative for COVID-19 using a test taken no more than five days before arrival. Travelers without such proof must submit to a test at the port of entry and face up to 14 days of quarantine at home or in a hotel of choice if positive. Authorities also perform temperature checks at airports. Travelers departing the country must also present negative results from COVID-19 test taken no more than five days before travel"    Source:  https://archive.is/kPkhZ

However - I did find that they do have support for business and lowering import duties and VAT for hygiene and healthcare goods and services critical to tackle COVID-19, and for tourism businesses; (ii) lowering other selected tax rates; (iii) delaying tax payments, and waiving late payment fines and penalties; (iv) suspending government fees charged on informal sector operators for rent, security and parking in urban markets; (v) lowering the licensing fee for companies in the transportation and tourism sectors; (vi) suspending on-site tax inspection operations; (vii) Donating food and providing assistance to households and local small businesses; (viii) supporting the water and electricity bills, including through cancelation, of the most vulnerable social groups; and (ix) securing adequate stocks of consumer products and strengthening surveillance of prices.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207221300/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There was a learning crisis in Botswana even before COVID-19 shuttered schools down. A third of grade 5 students in 2017 were unable to do basic subtraction and a fifth unable to read a simple paragraph.[i] This learning crisis will likely be worsened by school closures due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208003633/https://www.orfonline.org/expert-speak/education-in-2021-perspectives-from-botswana/

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. Botswana is divided into 9 geographical zones (map available at www.gov.bw) and permits are only needed to travel between zones.  Residents may travel within their zone without permits. Permits for inter-zone travel may be acquired online at www.gov.bw and are restricted to essential travel. COVID-19 tests may be required at any time for those transiting zones. Tourism is considered essential travel for economic reasons, and Botswana residents may organize permit applications with a reservation confirmation from their destination lodging.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? No. All persons entering Botswana are required to have a negative PCR test within 72 hours of their departure for Botswana. If they do not meet this requirement upon entry, they will be tested at the Port of Entry. With a negative test, they are not required to quarantine.  Persons who are symptomatic upon entry or who develop COVID after entry must self-isolate for 10 days with a test in the second half of the isolation period. Close contacts of positive COVID patients will be asked to isolate for 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All travellers arriving should have a valid 72 hour PCR negative test. COVID-19 Testing:    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Botswana? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? No  Antigen (rapid) tests are available at the international airports and major land border crossings. PCR tests are available for U.S. citizens at two locations: Sir Ketumile Masire Teaching Hospital and Diagnofirm Medical Laboratories, both in Gaborone.  Teaching Hospital PCR tests are 500 BWP and results can be slower than 48-72 hours as this is the main testing facility for everyone in country and is cheaper than Diagnofirm. Diagnofirm offers PCR tests for 999 BWP which are available in less than 24 hours. Antigen test costs range from 150 to 500 BWP. All testing is paid for by the patient. The Teaching Hospital price of 500 BWP is a price limit set by the Government of Botswana and is therefore partially subsidized.  Test results are delivered by text message/SMS. Expect delays in messaging even if the results are complete on time.  Testing regulations and information change frequently. If you are in Botswana and experiencing symptoms, contact your physician and the Government of Botswana COVID hotline at 997 for instructions.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions for travel to the United States, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  A national curfew is in place in response to outbreaks of violence, following presidential and legislative elections. This curfew comes into effect at 8pm and ends at 5am. You should follow the government’s instructions and avoid travel around Bangui during these hours.    The following measures remain in place:    it is compulsory to wear face masks in public places;  no handshakes or kissing, instead use non-contact greetings for social interactions;  public spaces must have hand-washing stations;  places of worship and restaurants remain open;  staying in your house or accommodation is encouraged.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210210124349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/coronavirus

Transportation Options:    Are commercial flights operating? Yes, however airline schedules often change with little notice. Please monitor your flight status on a continual basis.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Public transportation is considered dangerous and it is not recommended to travel by mini-bus or moto-taxis (motorcycles).  Private cabs are available.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213111451/https://cf.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Curfew remains in place due to civil unrest but no due to COVID   /web/20210208193757/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/coronavirus

Minimal domestic restrictions remain in place following the easing of measures in recent months; social distancing measures, including the use of protective facemasks, is compulsory in all public spaces and public transportation, though this measure is not strictly enforced. Noncontact greetings for social interactions are reportedly being enforced in Bangui. A security-related state of emergency and 1800-0500 curfew are in place.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210218142228/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/444751/central-african-republic-nationwide-covid-19-restrictions-remain-largely-unchanged-as-of-feb-18-update-5

https://web.archive.org/web/20210215141307/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/covid-4/coronavirus-central-african-republic    CDC advises people to take precautionary measures before, during and after travel.

Entry to CAR  Some incoming passengers need to undertake a (COVID-19) test on arrival. You should arrange to take a private test.    Some air companies and airports also require a negative COVID-19 test prior to boarding to CAR. You should check with your travel provider.    Do not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country.    Some of CAR neighbouring countries have started to re-open their land borders, including those with CAR This includes Democratic Republic of Congo and Sudan.    Screening on arrival  All travellers entering CAR are required to wear face masks, use hand sanitiser, have their body temperatures taken and disinfect luggage among other measures.    Quarantine requirements  14 days self-isolation is mandatory for any person entering CAR who is coming from a location with local transmission of COVID-19.    Airline companies must also cooperate with the government of CAR concerning quarantine and other measures necessary to manage the spread of coronavirus.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210222164636/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/entry-requirements

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in the Central African Republic? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  For symptomatic patients, testing is free and available at the Ministry of Health and Institute Pasteur.  For pre-departure testing, travelers should go to the Pasteur Institute in Bangui.  Their current hours are 7:00am to 11:15am Monday to Saturday and testing is first come, first serve.  Tests are approximately $75 and should be paid in local currency.   Tests are generally available within 48 hours via email.  https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/car/card/7jsVXwSZcV/  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to CDC’s requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID test, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  Humanitarian exemptions to this order will be granted on an extremely limited basis and will only be considered when the country of departure lacks adequate COVID-19 testing capacity. Minimal domestic restrictions remain in place following the easing of measures in recent months; social distancing measures, including the use of protective facemasks, is compulsory in all public spaces and public transportation, though this measure is not strictly enforced. Noncontact greetings for social interactions are reportedly being enforced in Bangui. A security-related state of emergency and 1800-0500 curfew are in place.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210218142228/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/444751/central-african-republic-nationwide-covid-19-restrictions-remain-largely-unchanged-as-of-feb-18-update-5

According to the US Embassy in Cameroon, the Cameroonian government has updated the previous policy of mandatory quarantine for travelers. Air passengers with a positive COVID-19 test result will be required to enter isolation at home or in a government facility at their own expense depending on their symptoms. Although quarantine is not required, travelers may have been exposed to COVID-19 during their travels and are encouraged to limit contact with others for 14 days after their trip. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221154149/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new information was gathered but in the second quarter of 2020, there was exemption from the withholding tax for taxis and motorbikes and petty traders.   Other measures aim to alleviate the impact on households, in particular (i) an increase in the family allowance from CFAF 2,800 to CFAF 4,500; (ii) a raise of 20 percent for pensions that did not benefit from the 2016 reform; (iii) continued payment of family allowances from May to July to staff of companies which are unable to pay social security contributions or which have placed their staff on technical leave due to the crisis.    Please see: https://archive.vn/VQK2X

According to the COVID -19 Stimulus tracker, the household allowance was increased from 2800 CFA to 4500 CFA in May of 2020. Please see: https://archive.vn/aRFaa  Here is a link to a reporting page on the change in policy. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221154731/https://www.businessincameroon.com/social/1305-10317-cnps-other-social-benefits-will-rise-with-the-family-allowance

The IMF tracker reported specific measures support the fight against the pandemic, notably (i) full income tax deductibility of donations and gifts made by companies for the fight against COVID-19, (ii) three-month suspension of the payment of parking and demurrage charges in the Douala and Kribi ports for essential goods; and (iii) the establishment of a MINFI-MINEPAT consultation framework aimed at mitigating the crisis and promoting a rapid resumption of activity.   There were announced in April 2020. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210131234221/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government in conjunction with the British High Commission in Cameroon made effort to address the COVID-19 pandemic in the country.  The British High Commission in Yaounde led the British Business Community in Cameroon on a distribution campaign dubbed, “UK in Cameroon COVID-19 Relief Caravan”. The purpose was to handover personal protective equipment (PPE), to over 10,000 persons within semi-urban and rural populations, with focus on vulnerable communities, women and persons living with disability.   Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210131235404/https://www.africanews.com/2021/01/27/coronavirus-uk-in-cameroon-covid-19-relief-caravan/

The US Embassy in CAmeroon confirms that testing is reliably available within 72 hours at the following centers;  Centre Pasteur and National Public Health Laboratory in Yaounde, and the Laquintinie Hospital in Douala. The Cameroon government has announced that these tests are free of charge.  Once the patient submits their sample, results are sent to him/her by email, text message, or physical copy within 24 hours unless otherwise specified by the testing facility. The country is still working hard to curb the virus. The country pledged about $1 million over the next 5 years to the Gavi Alliance. Please see: https://archive.vn/nfFvB

/web/20210215163126/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus  No policy updates, schools and universities remain closed
"social enterprises eg bars and nightclubs remain closed"    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus

Bars and "entertainment enterprises" remain closed. Some work places remain open but with social distancing measures encouraged   /web/20210215163126/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus
"Is public transportation operating? Yes"    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Restrictions have been placed on the number of people per vehicle for public transport.   /web/20210215163126/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus
"Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No"    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travellers moving from one province to another must present a negative coronavirus test result. The test result date must fall within 3 days before the date you intend to leave the province.   /web/20210215163126/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus

"Travelers entering the DRC, regardless of the origin of their travel, are not required to quarantine so long as they show a negative COVID-19 test taken within 7 days of departure from their point of origin and receive a negative COVID-19 test upon arrival.  Following the sample collection at the airport, travelers must self-quarantine until they receive a negative test result, generally within 24 hours.  "    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All travellers entering DRC are subject to screening, including temperature checks.    Travellers aged 11 and above need to provide proof of a negative coronavirus test upon entry to DRC. The test result date must be within the 7 days prior to your arrival date. Children under the age of 11 are exempt.    Travellers aged 11 and above must also pay $45 USD for a mandatory test on arrival    You must provide proof of a negative test for coronavirus upon departure. The test result date must fall within 3 days before your departure date and be provided by either INRB (Institut National de Recherche Biomédicale – The National Institute of Biomedical Research) or a medical facility approved by them.    You may be subjecting to screening, including temperature checks, when leaving DRC.  /web/20210215164738/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/entry-requirements
No policy found
No policy found

Coronavirus testing is available at the following main towns:  /web/20210215163126/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus  Kinshasa  Matadi  Lubumbashi  Goma  Kolwezi  Mbandaka  There are a variety of testing facilities and the price starts from $45 USD.    If you think you have coronavirus symptoms, you should call DRC government healthcare services on 101, 109, 110.

"Supporting rapid response actions in the epicenter of Kinshasa, including case investigations, contact tracing, and communications in the most affected health zones of Gombe, Binza-Ozone and Nsele (with financial support from Resolve to Save Lives). According to the government of Congo, bars and nightclubs remain closed as the state of emergency was extended for another 20 days from the 25th of January, 2021. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201003235/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

The state of emergency was extended by the government for 20 days from January 25, 2021. This period is still under the state of emergency rule. Bars and nightclubs are still closed. There has been no update on the government website. Please see the communique from January 21st, 2021.   Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207044617/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

The state of emergency has been extended for another 20 days beginning from the 14th of February, 2021. The government saw the progress that the country has gained in the time that it had been in place and proceeded to extend it. This maintained the closure of night clubs and dance houses. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

The state of emergency is still on. According to the government, bars and nightclubs are still closed. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221125448/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

According to the Congolese government, gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited. This consequently affects public events. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201003235/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

The government stipulated that marquee tents are banned and gatherings of people more than 50 are equally banned. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210207044617/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

The gatherings of people more than 50 is still prohibited by there is a proposition to drop this due to the coming elections to allow the citizens gather for political rallies while respecting the protocols for hygiene and social distancing in place. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

According to the government, there is a ban on the set up of marquee tents which consequentially affects public events. Although, the national coordination for the pandemic has requested flexibility in the measures to ensure rally are held while respecting the barriers in place for hygiene due to the upcoming presidential elections. Upon further research, no rallies have been held yet. Please see:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210221125448/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

According to the Congolese government, gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201003235/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

According to the Congolese government, more than 50 people cannot gather. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207044617/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

The fllowing restrictions are in place;  1. More than 50 people cannot gather.   2. To lift bodies from the morgue, only 10 family members are allowed to be present.   3. The opening of state markets in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire is limited to five days (Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday).   4. Group walks of more than three people on public roads and spaces, in particular the corniche and the surroundings of the Brazzaville stadiums as well as the shores of the Atlantic Ocean in Pointe-Noire and in the Kouilou are prohibited.  5. The installation on the track and public spaces of marquees intended to accommodate people is prohibited.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

Currently, the markets open for five days in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire (Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday). More than 3 people are not allowed to walk on public roads and spaces, in particular the corniche and the surroundings of the Brazzaville stadiums as well as the shores of the Atlantic Ocean in Pointe-Noire and in the Kouilou. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221125448/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/  The travel website for the UK government maintains that the restriction is pegged at 50 people. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221132353/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus

According to the US Embassy in Congo, all international passengers are required to self-quarantine for two weeks in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival. Passengers in transit will be quarantined at their expense at designated facilities until they resume their travels.  Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201004122/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
According to the US Embassy, the quarantine measures are still in place for foreigners. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207045006/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In addition to the quarantine measures, the government requires the presentation, at the border, of a negative PCR test of less than 72 hours for all passengers arriving in Congo, with the exception of children under ten (10) years old. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/    Also see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214140802/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The IMF COVID-19 Stimulus tracker states that $ billion CFA was provided for households. It has not been confirmed if the funding is still available or the intervention still current. The tracker cannot be archived. However, KPMG shared the same information. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201005253/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/republic-of-congo-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
No new data was gathered. Please see the last update from the IMF.   https://archive.vn/vHLrh

The world bank made provision for about $20 million and the state added 3 billion CFA which is equivalent to $5,542,680 according to exchange rate.org. (the rate as at 12th of February,2021 is 1 CFA to 0.001848 USD) will be made available for the 339,143 eligible households. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

The government mentioned the plan to provide economic support to members of the vulnerable population. A grant of a flat-rate allowance of 200,000 households, at the rate of 50,000 CFA francs per household. The additional resources granted by the World Bank (US $ 20 million) and State funding of around 3 billion CFA francs should be sufficient to pay the planned allocation to 339,143 eligible households. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221125448/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

The IMF states that the government has adopted some measures to ease tax and duty payments for private enterprises. In particular, more time has been given to companies to pay their taxes and tax assessments on site have been abandoned. The import duty directorate is also strongly encouraging electronic payment of dues and allowing more electronic documents to be accepted at the port. Corporate income tax has been reduced to 28 percent from 30 percent and the turnover tax has been reduced to 5 percent from 7 percent for small businesses with turnover below 100 million XAF, although these measures will apply in 2021.  Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201005218/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No new data was gathered. Please see the last update from the IMF.   https://archive.vn/vHLrh
There is no new information but here is what the IMF captured as at 4th of February 2021.   Please see: https://archive.vn/VQK2X
Not much is known but from the COVID 19 Stimulus tracker, there were free utilities during the lockdown. Please see: https://archive.vn/J0l50

The US Embassy in Congo provides information on testing in the major cities.   Brazzaville:  National public health laboratory, Laboratoire National de Santé Publique located in front of the people’s palace.  Congolese Foundation for Medical Research Fondation Congolaise de la Recherche Médicale. located at the city of research, château-d ’eau district (ex ORSTOM).  Pointe-Noire:    Branch of National Public Health Laboratory located inside the Loandjili general hospital.  Gombes Foundation laboratory, Laboratoire de la foundation Gombe’s located in the city center.  Oyo:    Laboratory of the infectious and tropical pathologies research center of the general hospital (CREPIT) Edith Lucie Bongo Ondimba  The days and times for testing and test results are as follows    – Testing (in all sites): From Monday to Saturday, from 08 to 10    Results will be available online: www.Insp-cg.org  Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201004122/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

With the exception of those given specific permits, the use of private cars and other individual means of transport will not be allowed in this period. With the exception of trade services related to the daily livelihood of people, all other trading enterprises will be closed.  The former will close at 8-00 pm every evening.  5.    Major productive and service sectors (manufacturing, agriculture, food processing, construction, etc.) will continue their functions.  6.    Citizens in the rural areas engaged in farming and animal husbandry will continue with their vital developmental tasks.  7.    All Government institutions will stop routine and other services other than indispensable functions of developmental, public utility and public safety and security nature.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104215114/https://shabait.com/2020/12/21/guidelines-from-the-high-level-task-force-on-covid-19-5/

In a "clarification" to the guidelines issued on December 21. the Eritrean High Level Task Force on Covid-19 is reported by the US Embassy in Eritrea to have announced that "Except those who work in activities related to development, safety, and essential services, everyone must avoid unnecessary movement and remain at home. Except for emergency cases or food purchases, all movement done – whether by foot, bicycle, cart, or car – is prohibited." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210104214528/https://er.usembassy.gov/december-26-announcement-from-the-eritrean-government-on-clarification-of-covid-19-guidelines/
This is a conservative logical deduction given general restrictions on internal movement and closure of businesses etc.

"Except for emergency cases or food purchases, all movement done – whether by foot, bicycle, cart, or car – is prohibited" - https://er.usembassy.gov/december-26-announcement-from-the-eritrean-government-on-clarification-of-covid-19-guidelines/

Guidelines from the High Level Task Force on COVID-19 https://web.archive.org/web/20210215025725/https://shabait.com/2020/12/21/guidelines-from-the-high-level-task-force-on-covid-19-5/ state that:    1.    Movement of all citizens will be restricted except in cases of indispensable developmental, service and security tasks that are authorized by the respective competent bodies.  2.    Travel from one village/city to another village/city in the country will be banned.  3.    With the exception of those given specific permits, the use of private cars and other individual means of transport will not be allowed in this period.  Trucks are exempted from this restriction for tasks limited to freight services only.

Policy: Under the guidelines, all citizens' movement is restricted except for essential personnel, such as security workers or those with special authorization. Travel from one village or city to another in the country is banned. Internal travel requires approval from authorities. Private vehicles and other individual means of transportation are not allowed to operate.     These policies are being enforced by local authorities and watch groups.   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210222090104/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/443016/eritrea-health-officials-maintain-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-feb-15-update-7

The Eritrean Ministry of Information reported that "public service messages and information about COVID-19 were developed and translated into all nine local languages (as well as sign language) and have been regularly disseminated through various forms of media (national television and radio). Safety, prevention, and hygiene guidelines have also been delivered through short message services for cellular telephones, and three “24/7” toll-free hotlines were established to provide information on health, hygiene, and prevention, and to report symptoms. Additionally, informational posters and pamphlets have been put on display in pharmacies, health clinics, shopping areas, on billboards and notice boards, and within other public spaces. Safety messages and themes were also integrated into popular television and radio programs, while popular artists recorded songs and videos supporting the national campaign against COVID-19." published November 2, 2020. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201112190842/https://shabait.com/2020/10/31/covid-19-eritreas-success-and-challenges-part-i/    No updates have been found since this time.

Schools in Gabon currently open.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210131150420/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Public places and services  Markets have reopened as normal.    Restaurants with a terrace have reopened. A valid negative COVID-19 tests is compulsory for access to a restaurant. Cost of tests are 5000 CFA or approximately £7.00.    Gatherings of more than 30 people are banned, however, parliament and educational institutions are exempt from this limit.    All place of worship can only open one day a week. Places of worship with a maximum of 30 people have to observe the ‘sanitary protocol’ which includes compulsory wearing of masks, hand sanitisation, and social distancing.    Schools have reopened.    Bars, beaches and places of worship remain closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215162704/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Latest Governmental Restrictions    Gabon    The Gabonese government has implemented the following COVID-19 measures:    To travel between cities in Gabon, travelers must show a negative COVID-19 result of a test within the previous 14 days.  Churches and indoor dining are open at a maximum occupancy of 30 people.  A curfew remains in effect (22:00 to 05:00).  Masks are still required in public and social distancing and hygiene requirements will continue. The government cautioned that restrictions may be reinstated in certain locations or throughout the country if new outbreaks occur.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125114716/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

All places of worship are permitted to open one day per week, with a limit of 30 participants at any given event.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210131134752/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/431266/gabon-several-covid-19-restrictions-maintained-nationwide-as-of-jan-19-update-12

Domestic measures    A nationwide curfew 2000-0500.    Social gatherings are limited to 30 people.    Facemasks are mandatory in public areas and on public transportation.    Travel in and out of Libreville is permitted so long as a negative COVID-19 test was taken no longer than 14 days before entry or departure is provided. It is not clear if the same regulations apply for travel elsewhere in the country.    There are capacity limits on public transport. Taxis may carry only three passengers.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125115708/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/433791/gabon-officials-adjust-the-covid-19-related-curfew-to-2000-0500-from-jan-25-update-13

Transportation Options    Are commercial flights operating?   Commercial air travel continues with three international flights per airline per week.  Crossing land and sea borders for commercial goods and services requires prior authorization.  Tourists are not permitted to arrive by land or sea.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are obligatory in all public transit vehicles. Taxis are operating at half capacity, limiting ridership to no more than 2 passengers per car.  Taxi buses are similarly limited in ridership.  In practice, however, many of these rules are ignored.

The prevalence of COVID-19 cases in Gabon has recently increased, and government restrictions have tightened. As of January 25, the government has extended the curfew hours to 20:00 to 05:00.  Beginning the evening of January 30, land borders were closed except for government-approved crossings.  The government is monitoring the situation closely and has warned it will impose strong restrictions again should the situation worsen appreciably.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210207231917/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to Gabon  Flight restrictions have eased to allow three flights per airline, per week. Land and sea borders are closed.    UK nationals must receive authorisation from the Gabonese Ministry of Foreign Affairs before travelling to Gabon. Authorisation can be obtained by sending an e-mail addressed to the ‘Minister’ or ‘Secretary General’ at the following e-mail address: ginetedzang2@gmail.com.    On arrival, all passengers must take a compulsory test for COVID-19 at Libreville Airport. Passengers are then required to self-isolate for 48 hours whilst the COVID-19 test is being processed. If the COVID-19 test is negative, passengers will be issued a test certificate, which is valid for 14 days and can be renewed at the end of this period after another test is undertaken.    If a COVID-19 test taken at the airport is positive, then passengers are required to continue self-isolation and await specific instructions from Gabonese health authorities. All COVID-19 tests taken in Gabon supersede any that were taken before arrival in Gabon.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210124212006/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/entry-requirements

The government also plans to allocate additional FCFA 108 billion (USD 194.1 million or 1.2 percent of GDP) as an economic response, including through food stamps, electricity and water subsidies, direct support to SMEs and tax holidays.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125121202/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

FISCAL  The Amended Budget Law approved in end-June 2020 proposes the control of non-priority expenditure and redirects savings and development partners support of FCFA 73.9 billion (USD 138.1 million or 0.83 percent of GDP) to COVID-19 related spending. The government also plans to allocate additional FCFA 108 billion (USD 194.1 million or 1.2 percent of GDP) as an economic response, including through food stamps, electricity and water subsidies, direct support to SMEs and tax holidays. The Minister of Finance has created a fund available at their Caisse de Depots et Consignation (CDC) and designated a public accountant in order to facilitate disbursements of the health-related spending of that fund. An additional mechanism of around USD 375 million has further been announced to facilitate access to commercial banks financing for private (formal and informal) companies, including SMEs.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210131145930/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change in policy.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210116132734/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus  http://web.archive.org/web/20210125121202/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Reopening of the economy. Since April 27, some of these measures were relaxed, including the full lockdown in Libreville. A second reopening wave started on July 1 with the reopening of commercial flights twice per week per company from Libreville and a reduced night curfew from 8pm till 5am. Since mid-August commercial flights were further relaxed to three flights per company per week departing from Gabon. Public schools reopened on November 7, 2020. Public gatherings are still not approved. Travelers departing to the countryside from the two main cities (Libreville and Franceville) must show a negative Covid-19 test performed up to five days prior to departure. Since early September, the test for domestic trips can be performed up to 14 days prior to departure. Travelers flying abroad must take the test if the destination country requires it, whereas all passengers arriving in Libreville’s airport must show a negative test performed in the last five days. At arrival, they are once more tested by Gabonese authorities in the airport for posterior tracing. On October 10, a new round of relaxation of the preventive measures have been announced, allowing restaurants and religious centers to resume activity and shortening the night curfew from 10pm till 5am. Such gradual reopening of the economy has been based on a comprehensive-testing strategy with a capability of around 10,000 tests to be performed per day and with the equivalent of more than fifteen percent of the population tested, making the country one with the highest rates of testing per capita of sub-Saharan Africa. The Gabonese parliament has also launched at the end of the first semester a Parliamentary Inquire Committee to investigate the quality and transparency of the Covid-19 expenditures by the government. The Ministry of Health is currently preparing a national vaccination strategy against the disease.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210201150110/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Reopening of the economy. Since April 27, some of these measures were relaxed, including the full lockdown in Libreville. A second reopening wave started on July 1 with the reopening of commercial flights twice per week per company from Libreville and a reduced night curfew from 8pm till 5am. Since mid-August commercial flights were further relaxed to three flights per company per week departing from Gabon. Public schools reopened on November 7, 2020. Public gatherings are still not approved. Travelers departing to the countryside from the two main cities (Libreville and Franceville) must show a negative Covid-19 test performed up to five days prior to departure. Since early September, the test for domestic trips can be performed up to 14 days prior to departure. Travelers flying abroad must take the test if the destination country requires it, whereas all passengers arriving in Libreville’s airport must show a negative test performed in the last five days. At arrival, they are once more tested by Gabonese authorities in the airport for posterior tracing. On October 10, a new round of relaxation of the preventive measures have been announced, allowing restaurants and religious centers to resume activity and shortening the night curfew from 10pm till 5am. Such gradual reopening of the economy has been based on a comprehensive-testing strategy with a capability of around 10,000 tests to be performed per day and with the equivalent of more than twenty percent of the population tested, making the country one with the highest rates of testing per capita of sub-Saharan Africa. The Gabonese parliament has also launched at the end of the first semester a Parliamentary Inquire Committee to investigate the quality and transparency of the Covid-19 expenditures by the government. The Ministry of Health is currently preparing a national vaccination strategy against the disease. At the same time a second wave of infections has hit the country and some of the preventive measures have been strengthened, such as the return to the extended night curfew from 8pm till 6am.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210208113328/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20210131150420/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in GABON? Yes, PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html.  COVID-19 PCR tests are 5,000 FCFA for in-country travel and 20,000 FCFA for international travel; these costs are covered by the individual requesting the testing.  A PCR test must be taken upon arrival in Gabon; the cost is now 20,000 FCFA per test.  The following sites offer COVID-19 testing in the greater Libreville area (https://infocovid.ga):  Hôpital de Campagne (Field Hospitals): Stade d’angondje  Centre de Santé (Health Centers): Awendje, Okala, Louis, Owendo, London, La Peyrie, Lalala, Nzeng Ayong, Glass  Centre Médicaux (Medical Centers): Ntoum  Hôpitaux (Hospitals): Hôpital de Nkembo, Hôpital Sino-gabonais, Hôpital égypto-gabonais  Centres Hospitaliers Régionaux (Regional Hospital Centers): MELEN  Centres Hospitaliers Universitaires (University Hospital Centers): Libreville, Owendo, Mère-Enfant Jeanne Ebori  Structures Privées (Private Institutions): Polyclinique Chambrier, Cabinet médical inter-entreprises, Cabinet ORL Dr Edzang  Unités Mobiles (Mobile Units): Gigi, aéroport, Charbonnages, Awendje, SNI  Hôpitaux Militaires (Military Hospitals): Akanda  Infirmeries Garde Républicaine (Republican Guard Clinics): Infirmerie principale, Groupement d’intervention parachutiste, Groupement aérien présidentiel  Infirmeries Gendarmerie Nationale (National Gendarmerie Clinics): Santé maternelle et infantile, Gros bouquet, Owendo  Infirmeries Forces De Police Nationale (National Police Force Clinics): Komo, Sorbonne, Santé maternelle et infantile Fopi  Infirmeries Forces Armées Gabonaises (Gabonese Armed Forces Clinics): Infirmerie principale Louembet (Baraka), 1er Régiment de parachutistes gabonais  Laboratoires (Laboratories): Laboratoire Professeur Daniel Gahouma, Laboratoire national de santé publique  COVID-19 test results are delivered to the patient by printed copy.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210207231917/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

Latest Governmental Restrictions    Gabon    The Gabonese government has implemented the following COVID-19 measures:    To travel between cities in Gabon, travelers must show a negative COVID-19 result of a test within the previous 14 days.  Churches and indoor dining are open at a maximum occupancy of 30 people.  A curfew remains in effect (22:00 to 05:00).  Masks are still required in public and social distancing and hygiene requirements will continue.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125114716/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/
In Gabon, facemasks are mandatory in public areas and on public transportation.    Source:

Domestic measures    A nationwide curfew 2000-0500.    Social gatherings are limited to 30 people.    Facemasks are mandatory in public areas and on public transportation.    Travel in and out of Libreville is permitted so long as a negative COVID-19 test was taken no longer than 14 days before entry or departure is provided. It is not clear if the same regulations apply for travel elsewhere in the country.    There are capacity limits on public transport. Taxis may carry only three passengers.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125115708/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/433791/gabon-officials-adjust-the-covid-19-related-curfew-to-2000-0500-from-jan-25-update-13  http://web.archive.org/web/20210131144656/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

The wearing of facemasks is obligatory in all public spaces, to include riding or driving in a vehicle with two or more persons inside. If driving alone, the driver is required to have a facemask to be used immediately upon exiting the vehicle.  Fines for not wearing a facemask will range from 25,000 to 200,000 FCFA.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215160241/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

According to the Ghana Health Service, all schools are open. https://web.archive.org/web/20210208172409/https://www.ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/cancelled.php

NIghtclubs remain closed    "As of Jan. 4, authorities in Ghana have maintained some restrictions to curb the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). These restrictions remain in place indefinitely.    International TravelLand and sea borders remain closed until further notice. The transport of essential goods and freight has continued, though delays are likely due to enhanced screening measures. However, Kotoka International Airport (ACC) has reopened for international passenger travel. Travelers arriving in Ghana must complete an online health declaration form prior to departure. A similar form will also be completed during the flight. Passengers must present a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test result taken no more than 72 hours prior to departure. Passengers aged five and above will be screened and tested at their expense at the port of entry. Domestic flights are ongoing.    Domestic MeasuresAuthorities have reopened sectors of the country's economy in a phased approach. Domestic overground transport has resumed with hygiene protocols for operators and vehicles. Tourist facilities, attractions, and local open-air drinking spots have been permitted to reopen. Beaches, bars, cinemas, and nightclubs remain closed until further notice. Public and private schools will be reopened from Jan. 15. Other measures have been eased, including restrictions on the number of worshipers at religious venues. Social restrictions, including a ban on mass gatherings, remain in place but were relaxed at an earlier date. Officials have placed a limit of up to 100 people on private events such as funerals. Some academic activities resumed across the country. The use of facemasks is compulsory, and residents must adhere to at least one meter of social distancing in all public spaces nationwide. Violators face large fines or custodial sentences."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104195259/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/425151/ghana-covid-19-restrictions-remain-in-place-nationwide-as-of-jan-4-update-15

Certain sectors remained closed or effectively banned, inclduing nightclubs, bars, religious events. https://web.archive.org/web/20210208172409/https://www.ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/cancelled.php

"As of Jan. 4, authorities in Ghana have maintained some restrictions to curb the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). These restrictions remain in place indefinitely.    International TravelLand and sea borders remain closed until further notice. The transport of essential goods and freight has continued, though delays are likely due to enhanced screening measures. However, Kotoka International Airport (ACC) has reopened for international passenger travel. Travelers arriving in Ghana must complete an online health declaration form prior to departure. A similar form will also be completed during the flight. Passengers must present a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test result taken no more than 72 hours prior to departure. Passengers aged five and above will be screened and tested at their expense at the port of entry. Domestic flights are ongoing.    Domestic MeasuresAuthorities have reopened sectors of the country's economy in a phased approach. Domestic overground transport has resumed with hygiene protocols for operators and vehicles. Tourist facilities, attractions, and local open-air drinking spots have been permitted to reopen. Beaches, bars, cinemas, and nightclubs remain closed until further notice. Public and private schools will be reopened from Jan. 15. Other measures have been eased, including restrictions on the number of worshipers at religious venues. Social restrictions, including a ban on mass gatherings, remain in place but were relaxed at an earlier date. Officials have placed a limit of up to 100 people on private events such as funerals. Some academic activities resumed across the country. The use of facemasks is compulsory, and residents must adhere to at least one meter of social distancing in all public spaces nationwide. Violators face large fines or custodial sentences."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104195259/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/425151/ghana-covid-19-restrictions-remain-in-place-nationwide-as-of-jan-4-update-15

Guinea is the only country, among the 29 world's poorest, to have a vaccination plan. However, only 55 people have been vaccinated in a pilot phase (with Sputnik V). There is no information about the number of doses that will be available and starting from when.

Around 55 people - mainly government officials - were vaccinated during the pilot phase, but no comprehensive vaccination policy is evident beyond this. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210209015411if_/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/01/26/guinea-covid-vaccinations-poor-countries/

Since January 9, all travellers arriving from countries where new strains of the coronavirus have been identified are required to undergo COVID testing upon arrival. Such travellers may also undergo mandatory quarantine at Gambian government-designated facilities, at the traveller’s own expense. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210209020546/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Since January 9, all travellers arriving from countries where new strains of the coronavirus have been identified will be required to undergo COVID testing upon arrival and may also undergo mandatory quarantine at Gambian government-designated facilities, at the traveller’s own expense. See: https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive not working, webpage last updated Feb 16th 2021]

Note: In early February, the government launched the first ever nation-wide study on Knowledge, Activity and Practices (KAP) on COVID-19. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210215214658/https://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/national-news/vp-touray-gambia-registers-highest-covid-19-in-africa [the web archive link was playing up, so in case of a broken link, the original article is this: https://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/national-news/vp-touray-gambia-registers-highest-covid-19-in-africa]

COVID-19 testing can be done at the Medical Research Council (MRC) in Fajara, or at several Gambian government-run testing facilities at Independence Stadium, Bakau, KMC; Buffer Zone in Latrikunda, KMC; Brusubi Main Roundabout, adjacent to Petroleum House, WCR; and Brikama, behind Mbalet Junction, WCR. Testing is typically available at the Gambian government-run sites Monday-Friday, and is provided at no cost.  See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210209020546/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
No vaccine rollout strategy yet and no vaccines have been approved at this point. See https://web.archive.org/web/20210209020546/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Note: The Gambian government has also no approved any COVID-19 vaccine for use. See https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive not working, webpage last updated Feb 16th 2021]

A package of tax measures has been adopted, including full income tax relief for persons earning below the equivalent of $225 per month, reduction of the top pay-as you earn rate from 30 to 25 percent, reduction of the base corporate income tax rate from 30 to 25 percent, reduction of the turnover tax rate on small businesses from 3 to 1 percent, and a reduction of the standard VAT rate from 16 to 14 percent. Some of the tax measures, including the reduction of top PAYE rate, corporate income tax rate and VAT were reversed effective January 1, 2021. Covid-19 Test Protocol @ RIA    For all non-travelers, sample collection is free.  All in-coming travelers staying more than 5 days have to be tested within 72 hours or three days before departure  Test results can be obtained from www.covidresults.org  All out-going travelers have to be tested within 72 hours or three days before departure  Sample Collection/Testing Center is located at Union Center, Sophie Road, Congo Town, Monrovia.   To obtain your certificate, visit  www.liberiacovidtravel.org  For questions or concerns, email us at unioncenter.lib@gmail.com or call +231776871219  Cost for testing is 75 USD for in-coming and out-going travelers.  Union Center is open for testing @ 8 AM to 4PM every day    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215202939/https://www.nphil.gov.lr/index.php/covid-19-travel-guidance/

Lesotho returned to “Orange Level” restrictions on 3 February 2021. Only essential businesses and services may operate. The list of essential businesses has been expanded to include street vendors and a wider range of retail outlets.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212141240/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Lesotho returned to “Orange Level” restrictions on 3 February 2021. Only essential businesses and services may operate. The list of essential businesses has been expanded to include street vendors and a wider range of retail outlets. All retail stores, hardware shops and supermarkets are permitted to operate between 8am-4pm. There are limits on customer numbers and regulations on sanitisation must be followed. Hair salons may operate an appointment-only service. No fitting services in clothes stores.  Liquor stores can operate Monday to Thursday between 10am and 4pm.  All over the counter essential service providers are permitted to operate with 50% maximum staff capacity. Digital payment methods are encouraged. Fuel stations may operate 24 hours.  Textile and manufacturing industries can operate at 50% capacity for both a day and night shift.  Hotels and restaurants may open. Hotels must restrict occupancy to one person per room unless they are spouses. No buffet or communal eating or private service bar is permitted. No conferences or workshops can be held. Restaurants, cafes and fast food outlets can operate a takeaway service. Gyms, parks and sporting facilities are closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222090556/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Only essential services, such as supermarkets and pharmacies are allowed to operate in line with safety protocols. Nearly all indoor and outdoor gatherings are prohibited. The Lesotho Ministry of Health has confirmed more than 8,900 cases of COVID-19 within its borders. Following a three-week lockdown period which increased the lockdown alert to “Red Level,” the government of Lesotho has decreased the lockdown alert to “Orange Level” effective February 3, 2020. The return to Orange Level maintains restrictions on many activities including mandatory masks in public places, a nationwide curfew each day from 9:00 pm to 5:00 am, and limits gatherings of any kind to a specified number of attendees.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207223802/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/

Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Entry into Lesotho currently prohibited for all travelers. On January 12, 2021, Prime Minister Moeketsi Majoro announced the closure Lesotho’s land borders and suspended all flights into the country, with limited exceptions. Negative COVID-19 Test Required: Any travelers to Lesotho will need to present a negative COVID-19 test not older than 72 hours from the time of departure. In Lesotho and Mexico, PIH made community engagement a central pillar in our COVID-19 response. Both teams focused on training and equipping community health workers with up-to-date information on the virus, personal protective equipment, and contact tracing tools. This community health approach—closely coordinated with local government systems—played a crucial part in connecting people to care effectively and reducing the toll of the disease on their lives.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201003139/https://www.pih.org/article/local-health-systems-key-responding-global-covid-19-pandemic-and-beyond

s PIH responds to COVID-19 in the U.S., we bring lessons learned from our infectious disease work globally, including our work with contact tracing during the Ebola outbreak in West Africa.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207234137/https://www.pih.org/article/local-health-systems-key-responding-global-covid-19-pandemic-and-beyond

Madagascar has suspended all routine international flights and private flights until further notice. Cruise ships are not currently permitted to berth in Madagascar’s ports.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122082800/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus

Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? U.S. citizens resident in Madagascar may return. Other U.S. visitors are not allowed.  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Yes  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  For free visa extensions (30 days renewable due to lockdown), travelers should go to the nearest Ministry of Interior, Immigration/Emigration office. This applies only for those who are stuck in Madagascar because of the suspension of flights and travel restrictions.  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes (but currently most U.S. citizens can’t enter)  Free testing is provided at the airport upon arrival in Nosy Be. Visitors are required to quarantine until COVID-19 test results come back.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131224645/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/

International flights to Nosy Be are allowed but other airports remain closed to international passengers.  However, travel from countries experiencing high numbers of COVID cases, is currently suspended.  All international flights to Madagascar are currently suspended, including private flights as of 16 January. Tourist flights to/from the island of Nosy Be restarted on 1 October, but onward travel to the mainland of Madagascar is not permitted. Travellers from countries on the risk list, cannot enter the country via this route.    http://archive.today/2021.02.15-122722/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/  http://archive.today/2021.02.15-123652/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus

Key Policy Responses as of January 6, 2021  FISCAL  Key measures include: (i) targeted investments to strengthen the health system following the activation of the national contingency plan in coordination with the WHO to protect against the pandemic; (ii) expansion of social assistance to the most vulnerable, including cash-transfers and in-kind necessities to the poorest and those unemployed; and (iii) supporting private sector through tax relief, suspension of government fees and waived social contributions. As of end of July, medicine and medical equipment were exempted from paying import duties.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122083848/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

As of end of July, medicine and medical equipment were exempted from paying import duties.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131230029/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

MONETARY AND MACRO-FINANCIAL  •	The central bank provided monetary policy support and acted to safeguard financial stability. The central bank is providing liquidity to the commercial banks, reaching MGA 609 billion (about 1.2 percent of GDP) at end December2020 and relaxed some mandatory deposit limits to encourage banks to defer delayed payments on existing loans and increase lending to businesses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122083848/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Some countries believed they were well organised enough to be able to manage any epidemic. They saw contact tracing – something used successfully to help track and contain outbreaks of Ebola in West Africa and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and the Plague in Madagascar – as a mechanism only poor countries use.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131231417/https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2020/10/7/contact-tracing-is-essential-to-break-covid-19-transmission

It's believed that Madagascar has contact tracing systems in place from previous experiences dealing with Ebola and Plague. Additionally, screening and tracing was used to identify specific positive cases and their residence previously.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215200009/https://www.who.int/hac/crises/mdg/en/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215193530/http://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites.html

The Government of Mali has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.  Any person who does not have a valid negative COVID-19 test result or is suspected of having COVID-19 will be isolated at the border and a COVID-19 test will be conducted.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Effective 26/01/2021 Any passenger who arrives without a negative COVID-19 test result or with a COVID-19 test result dated more than seven days before arrival will have their travel documents retained by airport officials and will be subjected to testing. Travelers must self-quarantine at home or at a hotel at their expense until the test result is available. Anyone suspected of having COVID-19, despite presenting a negative COVID-19 test result, will be subject to testing.  If test results are positive, that person’s travel documents will be retained, and the traveller will be put into isolation at a government of Mali facility.  The travel documents will be returned once the patient is deemed free of COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Air and land borders are open. Enhanced screening and quarantine measures are in place. Incoming travellers must present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before travel. "The Government of Mauritius has, in response to the COVID-19 situation, advised that individuals who have been in the UK within the previous 15 days will not be allowed entry to Mauritius. On 8 January 2021, the Government of Mauritius announced that this measure will be in force until at least 31 January 2021.    Since 1 October, to enter Mauritius, you must:  - Book airline travel and accommodation via the official Mauritian Tourism Promotion Agency website.  - Undergo a period of “in room” quarantine in a government-approved hotel on a full board basis for 14 days on arrival.  - Take a COVID-19 test no more than 7 days before your departure for Mauritius and demonstrate a negative test result on entry.  - Take a COVID-19 test on the day of arrival, and on day 7 and day 14 of your stay. If at any point, you receive a positive test result, you will be transferred to a public medical facility for treatment."    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210125035039/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/mauritius

A,B  Oxford-AstraZeneca  On January 26, Mauritius launched its Covid-19 vaccination program, with the first batch of 100.000 Indian-produced Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines donated from the Government of India. The priority is given to frontline workers including health care professionals and employees of the tourism industry, as well to senior citizens or those with underlying medical conditions.  https://archive.vn/usdt8#selection-16041.1859-16041.2230

A  Oxford-AstraZeneca  This donation of 100 000 doses of Covishield vaccines will assist Mauritius in its efforts to fight COVID-19 and in a first instance will be used to vaccinate some 50 000 frontliners including health workers and will contribute towards an early revival of crucial sectors of the Mauritian economy.  - https://archive.vn/GE3QG#selection-2773.117-2773.208

https://web.archive.org/web/20210125105334/https://theworldnews.net/mw-news/chakwera-address-jan-17-covid-19-demands-change-of-priorities-and-scaling-down-of-campaign-promises  For this reason, all schools will close for three weeks, but students in boarding schools will remain in their respective campuses until health authorities assess the severity of infection in those schools to determine whether it is safe for those students to go home.

No change. However, the Government of Malawi has issued on 4th February an extension of school closures "by another two weeks starting from 8th February, 2021".    See Malawi's Ministry of Education's Facebook post (contributor's note: the Government does not release most of its press releases on its own website), archived:  https://archive.vn/gG3cH

On 4 February, the Government of Malawi issued a press statement announcing "that school closure[s] will be extended by another two weeks, starting from 8th February, 2021". "All students in boarding secondary schools as well as residential students in colleges and universities should be released to go back home for these two weeks."    See Malawi's Ministry of Education's Facebook post (contributor's note: the Government does not release most of its press releases on its own website), archived:  https://archive.vn/gG3cH
No policy change but announcement that all schools will reopen on 22nd February   https://web.archive.org/web/20210221225116/https://www.facebook.com/malawimoh/posts/3617373071651515

No change in policy.    As per the US Embassy in Lilongwe on 28th Jan, "Beginning Monday, January 18, ... a curfew is in place from 9pm to 5am and all markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm. Hotels and lodges are operating but with strict COVID-19 measures."    See US Embassy's COVID-19 Information page, archived at https://archive.vn/t2IZs

No change in policy. "All activities that involve an audience, such as music shows, sports, arts, and religious gatherings, are restricted to 50 people or fewer."    See US Embassy in Malawi's COVID-19 Information page, archived at https://archive.vn/t2IZs

No change in policy. The US Embassy in Lilongwe notes on 22nd January that "the government has implemented other measures to limit the spread of the virus, including... no gathering of more than 50 people"    See the US Embassy's update on their website, archived at https://archive.vn/8WiDq  See also, the previous data point's archive (President's speech on 17th Jan), at https://web.archive.org/web/20210125105334/https://theworldnews.net/mw-news/chakwera-address-jan-17-covid-19-demands-change-of-priorities-and-scaling-down-of-campaign-promises

No policy changes. Latest communication on public transport was on 26 Jan, when the Ministry of Transport and Public Works issued a press release reiterating that "the gazetted Public Health (Corona Virus and Covid-19) (Prevention, Containment and Management) Rules 2020 are still in force", and that "all public service vehicles (Buses, Minibuses and Taxis) should reduce their seating capacity to 60% whilst observing social distance", and that "no standing passengers [are] allowed on any public service vehicle".    See Malawi Government's twitter post, archived at https://archive.vn/aaYnW, see aforementioned post's press release picture, archived at https://archive.vn/aCbfV
No policy change found.
No policy change found.

There is no change in policy. As per the US Embassy in Lilongwe on 22nd January, "the government of Malawi requires all arriving passengers to produce a negative SARS Cov-2 PCR test certificate obtained within 10 days prior to arrival and to complete a health declaration form.", and US citizens are permitted to enter (see Embassy's COVID-19 Information Page, archived at https://archive.vn/t2IZs)    There is no quarantine for arriving passengers. Per the 22nd Jan health alert update by the US Embassy in Lilongwe, "the government requests all arriving passengers to self-monitor for 14 days, after which district health officials will follow up with them". Random testing is in place in addition to the prevailing entry restrictions of furnishing a negative PCR test certificate - "Arriving passengers may be required to provide samples for Covid-19 testing. Samples will be collected at the airport and test results will be communicated to the concerned within 48 hours."    Additionally, "all land borders remain closed except for essential goods transporters, deportees, and those in special circumstances," and "foreigners may not travel to Malawi via land borders".    See archive at https://archive.vn/8WiDq (US Embassy Health Alert Update, 22 Jan), and https://archive.vn/t2IZs (US Embassy COVID-19 Information page, last updated 28 Jan)

No new policies found. There are no updates to IMF's own fiscal and economic policy tracker (last updated 7th Jan for Malawi), notes no updates to the policies that have lapsed at the end of last year.    See IMF's own website, archived at https://archive.vn/usdt8#M
No data to indicate either way
